abstract_summ: We aimed to detect SARS-CoV-2 surface and air contamination and study associated patient-level factors.METHODS: Air samples were collected by natural precipitation, and environmental surface samples were collected by conventional surface swabbing.RESULTS: All air samples were negative for SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the 6 patients singly isolated inside airborne infection isolation rooms (AIIRs) with 12 air changes per hour.None of SARS-Cov-2 RNA was detected among the 36 objects surface samples and 9 staffs PPE samples in isolation wards.Findings: The 107 surface samples comprised 37 from toilets, 34 from other surfaces in isolation rooms (ventilated at 30-60 L/s), and 36 from other surfaces outside isolation rooms in the hospital.

title_abstract_phrases: We aimed to detect SARS-CoV-2 surface and air contamination and study associated patient-level factors.METHODS: Air samples were collected by natural precipitation, and environmental surface samples were collected by conventional surface swabbing.RESULTS: All air samples were negative for SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the 6 patients singly isolated inside airborne infection isolation rooms (AIIRs) with 12 air changes per hour.Investigating SARS-CoV-2 surface and air contamination in an acute healthcare setting during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic in London.The findings may have important implications for modifying and developing urgently needed policy to better protect healthcare workers during this ongoing pandemic of SARS-CoV-2.Investigating SARS-CoV-2 surface and air contamination in an acute healthcare setting during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic in LondonObjectives: To evaluate SARS-CoV-2 surface and air contamination during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic in London.
